Famous for its bohemian past, head to Washington Square Park to get a feel for this diverse and energetic neighborhood. You’ll find NYU students, street performers, skateboarders, kids frolicking in the fountain, and locals relaxing and playing chess. Stroll the streets to discover a mix of majestic town homes and hidden bars and restaurants that give this neighborhood an old-school residential feel. When the sun goes down, check out one of the famous jazz or comedy clubs that still packs them in every night.

title: relatively cheap and cheerful
review: Stayed here for 5 nights in June 05. $195 /pn + tax for a budget hotel -  but hey it's NYC! The rooms are smallish but very clean. Security staff on front door at all times - I think that is because of the proximity to Washington Sq. Park, which during daylight is a fun place with lots of musicans and people-watching but at night - not so plesant! The front desk staff are fine and helpful - restaurant staff a little grumpy- but complimentary breakfast is adequate. The hotel has a great litttle bar(with wi-fi) but it was most used by laptoppers - not tipplers! 2 metro stations nearby and buses stops for uptown and downtown Great restaurants and bars within walking distance. I live in San Francisco and found NY a much safer place, especially at night.h We had a great trip - and…

title: Clean & Safe
review: Whenever I visit NYC I stay in this beautifully located hotel. The rooms are simple, but efficient. (But bring candles to give the room ambiente!) The bathrooms are quite spacy and have a window. If you're staying in the double bedroom with q-size bed ask for the higher floors, as you will have a lovely view of the Village even from your bathroom! The staff is friendly and helpful. Breakfast (included) is very sober, but there are many nice breakfast places and restaurants in the area. The location is superb: within walking distance from SoHo, East Village, West Village, Union Square, Meat Packing District, Chelsea etc. Subwaystations around the corner. Very good price value!

title: Great Location, simple, small rooms! good value
review: The room we had in this hotel was clean but simple.  The rooms are not large but are adequate.  Bathroom was very clean, fresh towels each day, maid service was excellent.  Great location, close to many restaurants and sights.  Continental  breakfast included with room at $199/night.   Looking forward to staying again next time we are in NYC.

title: Nice hotel at even nicer location!
review: Commonly known as “the Village” to New Yorkers, it was here in Greenwich Village that both 1960’s counter culture and the LGBT movement were born. Famous for its bohemian past, head to Washington Square Park to get a feel for this diverse and energetic neighborhood. You’ll find NYU students, street performers, skateboarders, kids frolicking in the fountain, and locals relaxing and playing chess. Stroll the streets to discover a mix of majestic town homes and hidden bars and restaurants that give this neighborhood an old-school residential feel. When the sun goes down, check out one of the famous jazz or comedy clubs that still packs them in every night.

title: Room 125 Hell On Earth
review: We stayed at WSH between march 25 - april 1. We had a "superior" room (whick is the cheaper one) with twin beds. The room was small but quite nice, perhaps a little bit sterile with nothing on the walls. The beds and linens were of very high standards, we slept well except from a couple of nights when noise from the corridor woke us up early. The bathroom was modern and fresh. The towels were clean and changed every day. The cleaning of the room was excellent.   Breakfast (included in room price of about $200 a night) was a fruit sallad and bagel/toast with coffee and tea. They can make you an omelett or something else if you want, if you pay extra for it. The breakfast tasted good and the dining room was nice, in the "art deco" - design as the lobby of the hotel.   The location…

title: super little haven
review: Stay away! The only good thing about this dump is the position – close to the subway and walking distance to Soho, Chinatown, Little Italy and The Village. Otherwise, pay a little extra and stay somewhere else. We’d prepaid the room through a travel agent in Australia and found a poky space barely big enough for the bed, just off the lobby and on a direct route from the lobby through to the restaurant – with the marble corridor, we were kept awake through the night with people walking past. The noise from the restaurant below (the kitchen staff were playing the radio loudly as they packed up for the night) made it even worse, as did the exhaust fans from the kitchen in the airshaft right outside our window, which had to be kept open (even in the cold of winter when we were…

title: Loved This Hotel!!!
review: Commonly known as “the Village” to New Yorkers, it was here in Greenwich Village that both 1960’s counter culture and the LGBT movement were born. Famous for its bohemian past, head to Washington Square Park to get a feel for this diverse and energetic neighborhood. You’ll find NYU students, street performers, skateboarders, kids frolicking in the fountain, and locals relaxing and playing chess. Stroll the streets to discover a mix of majestic town homes and hidden bars and restaurants that give this neighborhood an old-school residential feel. When the sun goes down, check out one of the famous jazz or comedy clubs that still packs them in every night.

title: Loved our stay here!!
review: I stayed at the Washington Square Hotel for 11 nights over New Year with 4 friends and we thought it was perfect. The staff are all extremely friendly and helpful, with nothing being too much trouble. We had a free breakfast included and although they don't start serving until after 7:30 this wasn't a problem for us at all! It is well situated with cafe's, pubs, restaurants, shops and subway stations all within walking distance. All in all, I would definitely stay here again!

title: Served its purpose, good location
review: Commonly known as “the Village” to New Yorkers, it was here in Greenwich Village that both 1960’s counter culture and the LGBT movement were born. title: tinpot establishment
review: Just back from 4 nights in the Washington Square HOtel.  I was there with an old school pal and we wanted to shop and see New York.  We had a renovated twin room which was adequate.  It was clean and fresh and the beds were comfortable.  The bathroom was also clean.  We were on the 8th floor so no noise problems and after reading some reviews on this site were actually relieved by the size and condition of the room.  So pay the extra $15 per night and get a renovated room!  Location was good for dinners and drinks in the evening and also shopping in SoHO.  Breakfast filled a gap but not a highlight.  Would stay there again as would not want to pay more than $200.00 per night for a hotel room.

title: Definitely a One-Time Experience
review: we have 'roughed it' in motel rooms across USA but found conditions at this hotel easily the poorest.  We were given a room just off the lobby area behind the reception. Outside was a skip full of dirty linen and vacuum cleaners were lined up. We assumed this was a storage area for janitor as time was 7pm. Condition of decor was appalling and it became clear the vacuums had seen no action in that room for some time. Room had many problems. faulty hissing radiator, buzzing lightbulbs, excessive dust, dirty cupboards, old sweetwrappers and alarmingly a broken insecure window (room was ground floor) NO apology offered. they were more concerned that we might have disturbed the 'clean' room! They were keen for us to take this particular room and it occured to us that they wanted to…

review: Commonly known as “the Village” to New Yorkers, it was here in Greenwich Village that both 1960’s counter culture and the LGBT movement were born. title: squirrels ran through my pajamas
review: I have stayed at the Washington Square Hotel many times in recent years.  It is the perfect New York hotel for anyone who is tired of the cookie cutter hotels that all look alike.  The hotel has been here for 100 years so anyone looking for new construction should look elsewhere.  But, if you are interested in something different and something with a history, this is the place for you.  The location is excellent, right on Washington Square and just blocks from SoHo and the subway. The staff is excellent, attentive and not intrusive. The rooms are cozy with very comfortable beds and warm duvets.  Hot water is plentiful and there are soft towels and bathrobes to lounge in. The public areas and rooms are imaginatively decorated, a beautiful tile painting of Sargent’s Madame X is in…
